text: God, having in the past spoken to the fathers through the prophets at many times and in various ways,
speaker: Narrator

text: has at the end of these days spoken to us by his Son, whom he appointed heir of all things, through whom also he made the worlds.
speaker: Narrator

text: His Son is the radiance of his glory, the very image of his substance, and upholding all things by the word of his power, who, when he had by himself purified us of our sins, sat down on the right hand of the Majesty on high,
speaker: Narrator

text: having become as much better than the angels as the more excellent name he has inherited is better than theirs.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For to which of the angels did he say at any time,
“You are my Son.
    Today I have become your father?”
and again,
“I will be to him a Father,
    and he will be to me a Son?”
speaker: Narrator

text: When he again brings in the firstborn into the world he says, “Let all the angels of God worship him.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Of the angels he says,
“He makes his angels winds,
    and his servants a flame of fire.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
But of the Son he says,
“Your throne, O God, is forever and ever.
    The scepter of uprightness is the scepter of your Kingdom.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You have loved righteousness and hated iniquity;
    therefore God, your God, has anointed you with the oil of gladness above your fellows.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
And,
“You, Lord, in the beginning, laid the foundation of the earth.
    The heavens are the works of your hands.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They will perish, but you continue.
    They all will grow old like a garment does.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You will roll them up like a mantle,
    and they will be changed;
    but you are the same.
    Your years won’t fail.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
But which of the angels has he told at any time,
“Sit at my right hand,
    until I make your enemies the footstool of your feet?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Aren’t they all serving spirits, sent out to do service for the sake of those who will inherit salvation?
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore we ought to pay greater attention to the things that were heard, lest perhaps we drift away.
speaker: Narrator

text: For if the word spoken through angels proved steadfast, and every transgression and disobedience received a just penalty,
speaker: Narrator

text: how will we escape if we neglect so great a salvation—which at the first having been spoken through the Lord, was confirmed to us by those who heard,
speaker: Narrator

text: God also testifying with them, both by signs and wonders, by various works of power, and by gifts of the Holy Spirit, according to his own will?
speaker: Narrator

text: For he didn’t subject the world to come, of which we speak, to angels.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But one has somewhere testified, saying,
“What is man, that you think of him?
    Or the son of man, that you care for him?
speaker: Narrator

text:
You made him a little lower than the angels.
    You crowned him with glory and honor.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You have put all things in subjection under his feet.”
For in that he subjected all things to him, he left nothing that is not subject to him. But now we don’t yet see all things subjected to him.
speaker: Narrator

text: But we see him who has been made a little lower than the angels, Jesus, because of the suffering of death crowned with glory and honor, that by the grace of God he should taste of death for everyone.
speaker: Narrator

text: For it became him, for whom are all things and through whom are all things, in bringing many children to glory, to make the author of their salvation perfect through sufferings.
speaker: Narrator

text: For both he who sanctifies and those who are sanctified are all from one, for which cause he is not ashamed to call them brothers,
speaker: Narrator

text:
saying,
“I will declare your name to my brothers.
    Among the congregation I will sing your praise.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Again, “I will put my trust in him.” Again, “Behold, here I am with the children whom God has given me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Since then the children have shared in flesh and blood, he also himself in the same way partook of the same, that through death he might bring to nothing him who had the power of death, that is, the devil,
speaker: Narrator

text: and might deliver all of them who through fear of death were all their lifetime subject to bondage.
speaker: Narrator

text: For most certainly, he doesn’t give help to angels, but he gives help to the offspring of Abraham.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore he was obligated in all things to be made like his brothers, that he might become a merciful and faithful high priest in things pertaining to God, to make atonement for the sins of the people.
speaker: Narrator

text: For in that he himself has suffered being tempted, he is able to help those who are tempted.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore, holy brothers, partakers of a heavenly calling, consider the Apostle and High Priest of our confession: Jesus,
speaker: Narrator

text: who was faithful to him who appointed him, as also Moses was in all his house.
speaker: Narrator

text: For he has been counted worthy of more glory than Moses, because he who built the house has more honor than the house.
speaker: Narrator

text: For every house is built by someone; but he who built all things is God.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses indeed was faithful in all his house as a servant, for a testimony of those things which were afterward to be spoken,
speaker: Narrator

text: but Christ is faithful as a Son over his house. We are his house, if we hold fast our confidence and the glorying of our hope firm to the end.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Therefore, even as the Holy Spirit says,
“Today if you will hear his voice,
speaker: Narrator

text:
don’t harden your hearts as in the rebellion,
    in the day of the trial in the wilderness,
speaker: Narrator

text:
where your fathers tested me and tried me,
    and saw my deeds for forty years.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Therefore I was displeased with that generation,
    and said, ‘They always err in their heart,
    but they didn’t know my ways.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
As I swore in my wrath,
    ‘They will not enter into my rest.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: Beware, brothers, lest perhaps there might be in any one of you an evil heart of unbelief, in falling away from the living God;
speaker: Narrator

text: but exhort one another day by day, so long as it is called “today”, lest any one of you be hardened by the deceitfulness of sin.
speaker: Narrator

text: For we have become partakers of Christ, if we hold the beginning of our confidence firm to the end,
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text: For who, when they heard, rebelled? Wasn’t it all those who came out of Egypt led by Moses?
speaker: Narrator

text: With whom was he displeased forty years? Wasn’t it with those who sinned, whose bodies fell in the wilderness?
speaker: Narrator

text: To whom did he swear that they wouldn’t enter into his rest, but to those who were disobedient?
speaker: Narrator

text: We see that they weren’t able to enter in because of unbelief.
speaker: Narrator

text: Let’s fear therefore, lest perhaps anyone of you should seem to have come short of a promise of entering into his rest.
speaker: Narrator

text: For indeed we have had good news preached to us, even as they also did, but the word they heard didn’t profit them, because it wasn’t mixed with faith by those who heard.
speaker: Narrator

text: For we who have believed do enter into that rest, even as he has said, “As I swore in my wrath, they will not enter into my rest;” although the works were finished from the foundation of the world.
speaker: Narrator

text: For he has said this somewhere about the seventh day, “God rested on the seventh day from all his works;”
speaker: Narrator

text: and in this place again, “They will not enter into my rest.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Seeing therefore it remains that some should enter into it, and they to whom the good news was preached before failed to enter in because of disobedience,
speaker: Narrator

text:
he again defines a certain day, “today”, saying through David so long a time afterward (just as has been said),
“Today if you will hear his voice,
    don’t harden your hearts.”
speaker: Narrator

text: For if Joshua had given them rest, he would not have spoken afterward of another day.
speaker: Narrator

text: There remains therefore a Sabbath rest for the people of God.
speaker: Narrator

text: For he who has entered into his rest has himself also rested from his works, as God did from his.
speaker: Narrator

text: Let’s therefore give diligence to enter into that rest, lest anyone fall after the same example of disobedience.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the word of God is living and active, and sharper than any two-edged sword, piercing even to the dividing of soul and spirit, of both joints and marrow, and is able to discern the thoughts and intentions of the heart.
speaker: Narrator

text: There is no creature that is hidden from his sight, but all things are naked and laid open before the eyes of him to whom we must give an account.
speaker: Narrator

text: Having then a great high priest who has passed through the heavens, Jesus, the Son of God, let’s hold tightly to our confession.
speaker: Narrator

text: For we don’t have a high priest who can’t be touched with the feeling of our infirmities, but one who has been in all points tempted like we are, yet without sin.
speaker: Narrator

text: Let’s therefore draw near with boldness to the throne of grace, that we may receive mercy and may find grace for help in time of need.
speaker: Narrator

text: For every high priest, being taken from among men, is appointed for men in things pertaining to God, that he may offer both gifts and sacrifices for sins.
speaker: Narrator

text: The high priest can deal gently with those who are ignorant and going astray, because he himself is also surrounded with weakness.
speaker: Narrator

text: Because of this, he must offer sacrifices for sins for the people, as well as for himself.
speaker: Narrator

text: Nobody takes this honor on himself, but he is called by God, just like Aaron was.
speaker: Narrator

text:
So also Christ didn’t glorify himself to be made a high priest, but it was he who said to him,
“You are my Son.
    Today I have become your father.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
As he says also in another place,
“You are a priest forever,
    after the order of Melchizedek.”
speaker: Narrator

text: He, in the days of his flesh, having offered up prayers and petitions with strong crying and tears to him who was able to save him from death, and having been heard for his godly fear,
speaker: Narrator

text: though he was a Son, yet learned obedience by the things which he suffered.
speaker: Narrator

text: Having been made perfect, he became to all of those who obey him the author of eternal salvation,
speaker: Narrator

text: named by God a high priest after the order of Melchizedek.
speaker: Narrator

text: About him we have many words to say, and hard to interpret, seeing you have become dull of hearing.
speaker: Narrator

text: For although by this time you should be teachers, you again need to have someone teach you the rudiments of the first principles of the revelations of God. You have come to need milk, and not solid food.
speaker: Narrator

text: For everyone who lives on milk is not experienced in the word of righteousness, for he is a baby.
speaker: Narrator

text: But solid food is for those who are full grown, who by reason of use have their senses exercised to discern good and evil.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore leaving the teaching of the first principles of Christ, let’s press on to perfection—not laying again a foundation of repentance from dead works, of faith toward God,
speaker: Narrator

text: of the teaching of baptisms, of laying on of hands, of resurrection of the dead, and of eternal judgment.
speaker: Narrator

text: This will we do, if God permits.
speaker: Narrator

text: For concerning those who were once enlightened and tasted of the heavenly gift, and were made partakers of the Holy Spirit,
speaker: Narrator

text: and tasted the good word of God and the powers of the age to come,
speaker: Narrator

text: and then fell away, it is impossible to renew them again to repentance; seeing they crucify the Son of God for themselves again, and put him to open shame.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the land which has drunk the rain that comes often on it and produces a crop suitable for them for whose sake it is also tilled, receives blessing from God;
speaker: Narrator

text: but if it bears thorns and thistles, it is rejected and near being cursed, whose end is to be burned.
speaker: Narrator

text: But, beloved, we are persuaded of better things for you, and things that accompany salvation, even though we speak like this.
speaker: Narrator

text: For God is not unrighteous, so as to forget your work and the labor of love which you showed toward his name, in that you served the saints, and still do serve them.
speaker: Narrator

text: We desire that each one of you may show the same diligence to the fullness of hope even to the end,
speaker: Narrator

text: that you won’t be sluggish, but imitators of those who through faith and perseverance inherited the promises.
speaker: Narrator

text: For when God made a promise to Abraham, since he could swear by no one greater, he swore by himself,
speaker: Narrator

text: saying, “Surely blessing I will bless you, and multiplying I will multiply you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Thus, having patiently endured, he obtained the promise.
speaker: Narrator

text: For men indeed swear by a greater one, and in every dispute of theirs the oath is final for confirmation.
speaker: Narrator

text: In this way God, being determined to show more abundantly to the heirs of the promise the immutability of his counsel, interposed with an oath,
speaker: Narrator

text: that by two immutable things, in which it is impossible for God to lie, we may have a strong encouragement, who have fled for refuge to take hold of the hope set before us.
speaker: Narrator

text: This hope we have as an anchor of the soul, a hope both sure and steadfast and entering into that which is within the veil,
speaker: Narrator

text: where as a forerunner Jesus entered for us, having become a high priest forever after the order of Melchizedek.
speaker: Narrator

text: For this Melchizedek, king of Salem, priest of God Most High, who met Abraham returning from the slaughter of the kings and blessed him,
speaker: Narrator

text: to whom also Abraham divided a tenth part of all (being first, by interpretation, “king of righteousness”, and then also “king of Salem”, which means “king of peace”,
speaker: Narrator

text: without father, without mother, without genealogy, having neither beginning of days nor end of life, but made like the Son of God), remains a priest continually.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now consider how great this man was, to whom even Abraham the patriarch gave a tenth out of the best plunder.
speaker: Narrator

text: They indeed of the sons of Levi who receive the priest’s office have a commandment to take tithes from the people according to the law, that is, of their brothers, though these have come out of the body of Abraham,
speaker: Narrator

text: but he whose genealogy is not counted from them has accepted tithes from Abraham, and has blessed him who has the promises.
speaker: Narrator

text: But without any dispute the lesser is blessed by the greater.
speaker: Narrator

text: Here people who die receive tithes, but there one receives tithes of whom it is testified that he lives.
speaker: Narrator

text: We can say that through Abraham even Levi, who receives tithes, has paid tithes,
speaker: Narrator

text: for he was yet in the body of his father when Melchizedek met him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now if perfection was through the Levitical priesthood (for under it the people have received the law), what further need was there for another priest to arise after the order of Melchizedek, and not be called after the order of Aaron?
speaker: Narrator

text: For the priesthood being changed, there is of necessity a change made also in the law.
speaker: Narrator

text: For he of whom these things are said belongs to another tribe, from which no one has officiated at the altar.
speaker: Narrator

text: For it is evident that our Lord has sprung out of Judah, about which tribe Moses spoke nothing concerning priesthood.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is yet more abundantly evident, if after the likeness of Melchizedek there arises another priest,
speaker: Narrator

text: who has been made, not after the law of a fleshly commandment, but after the power of an endless life;
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text: For there is an annulling of a foregoing commandment because of its weakness and uselessness
speaker: Narrator

text: (for the law made nothing perfect), and a bringing in of a better hope, through which we draw near to God.
speaker: Narrator

text: Inasmuch as he was not made priest without the taking of an oath
speaker: Narrator

text:
(for they indeed have been made priests without an oath), but he with an oath by him that says of him,
“The Lord swore and will not change his mind,
    ‘You are a priest forever,
    according to the order of Melchizedek.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: By so much, Jesus has become the guarantee of a better covenant.
speaker: Narrator

text: Many, indeed, have been made priests, because they are hindered from continuing by death.
speaker: Narrator

text: But he, because he lives forever, has his priesthood unchangeable.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore he is also able to save to the uttermost those who draw near to God through him, seeing that he lives forever to make intercession for them.
speaker: Narrator

text: For such a high priest was fitting for us: holy, guiltless, undefiled, separated from sinners, and made higher than the heavens;
speaker: Narrator

text: who doesn’t need, like those high priests, to offer up sacrifices daily, first for his own sins, and then for the sins of the people. For he did this once for all, when he offered up himself.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the law appoints men as high priests who have weakness, but the word of the oath, which came after the law, appoints a Son forever who has been perfected.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now in the things which we are saying, the main point is this: we have such a high priest, who sat down on the right hand of the throne of the Majesty in the heavens,
speaker: Narrator

text: a servant of the sanctuary and of the true tabernacle which the Lord pitched, not man.
speaker: Narrator

text: For every high priest is appointed to offer both gifts and sacrifices. Therefore it is necessary that this high priest also have something to offer.
speaker: Narrator

text: For if he were on earth, he would not be a priest at all, seeing there are priests who offer the gifts according to the law,
speaker: Narrator

text: who serve a copy and shadow of the heavenly things, even as Moses was warned by God when he was about to make the tabernacle, for he said, “See, you shall make everything according to the pattern that was shown to you on the mountain.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But now he has obtained a more excellent ministry, by as much as he is also the mediator of a better covenant, which on better promises has been given as law.
speaker: Narrator

text: For if that first covenant had been faultless, then no place would have been sought for a second.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator
Narrator

text:
“For this is the covenant that I will make with the house of Israel
    after those days,” says the Lord:
“I will put my laws into their mind;
    I will also write them on their heart.
I will be their God,
    and they will be my people.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They will not teach every man his fellow citizen
    and every man his brother, saying, ‘Know the Lord,’
    for all will know me,
    from their least to their greatest.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For I will be merciful to their unrighteousness.
    I will remember their sins and lawless deeds no more.”
speaker: Narrator

text: In that he says, “A new covenant”, he has made the first obsolete. But that which is becoming obsolete and grows aged is near to vanishing away.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now indeed even the first covenant had ordinances of divine service and an earthly sanctuary.
speaker: Narrator

text: For a tabernacle was prepared. In the first part were the lamp stand, the table, and the show bread, which is called the Holy Place.
speaker: Narrator

text: After the second veil was the tabernacle which is called the Holy of Holies,
speaker: Narrator

text: having a golden altar of incense and the ark of the covenant overlaid on all sides with gold, in which was a golden pot holding the manna, Aaron’s rod that budded, and the tablets of the covenant;
speaker: Narrator

text: and above it cherubim of glory overshadowing the mercy seat, of which things we can’t speak now in detail.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now these things having been thus prepared, the priests go in continually into the first tabernacle, accomplishing the services,
speaker: Narrator

text: but into the second the high priest alone, once in the year, not without blood, which he offers for himself and for the errors of the people.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Holy Spirit is indicating this, that the way into the Holy Place wasn’t yet revealed while the first tabernacle was still standing.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is a symbol of the present age, where gifts and sacrifices are offered that are incapable, concerning the conscience, of making the worshiper perfect,
speaker: Narrator

text: being only (with foods and drinks and various washings) fleshly ordinances, imposed until a time of reformation.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Christ having come as a high priest of the coming good things, through the greater and more perfect tabernacle, not made with hands, that is to say, not of this creation,
speaker: Narrator

text: nor yet through the blood of goats and calves, but through his own blood, entered in once for all into the Holy Place, having obtained eternal redemption.
speaker: Narrator

text: For if the blood of goats and bulls, and the ashes of a heifer sprinkling those who have been defiled, sanctify to the cleanness of the flesh,
speaker: Narrator

text: how much more will the blood of Christ, who through the eternal Spirit offered himself without defect to God, cleanse your conscience from dead works to serve the living God?
speaker: Narrator

text: For this reason he is the mediator of a new covenant, since a death has occurred for the redemption of the transgressions that were under the first covenant, that those who have been called may receive the promise of the eternal inheritance.
speaker: Narrator

text: For where a last will and testament is, there must of necessity be the death of him who made it.
speaker: Narrator

text: For a will is in force where there has been death, for it is never in force while he who made it lives.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore even the first covenant has not been dedicated without blood.
speaker: Narrator

text: For when every commandment had been spoken by Moses to all the people according to the law, he took the blood of the calves and the goats, with water and scarlet wool and hyssop, and sprinkled both the book itself and all the people,
speaker: Narrator

text: saying, “This is the blood of the covenant which God has commanded you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: He sprinkled the tabernacle and all the vessels of the ministry in the same way with the blood.
speaker: Narrator

text: According to the law, nearly everything is cleansed with blood, and apart from shedding of blood there is no remission.
speaker: Narrator

text: It was necessary therefore that the copies of the things in the heavens should be cleansed with these, but the heavenly things themselves with better sacrifices than these.
speaker: Narrator

text: For Christ hasn’t entered into holy places made with hands, which are representations of the true, but into heaven itself, now to appear in the presence of God for us;
speaker: Narrator

text: nor yet that he should offer himself often, as the high priest enters into the holy place year by year with blood not his own,
speaker: Narrator

text: or else he must have suffered often since the foundation of the world. But now once at the end of the ages, he has been revealed to put away sin by the sacrifice of himself.
speaker: Narrator

text: Inasmuch as it is appointed for men to die once, and after this, judgment,
speaker: Narrator

text: so Christ also, having been offered once to bear the sins of many, will appear a second time, not to deal with sin, but to save those who are eagerly waiting for him.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the law, having a shadow of the good to come, not the very image of the things, can never with the same sacrifices year by year, which they offer continually, make perfect those who draw near.
speaker: Narrator

text: Or else wouldn’t they have ceased to be offered, because the worshipers, having been once cleansed, would have had no more consciousness of sins?
speaker: Narrator

text: But in those sacrifices there is a yearly reminder of sins.
speaker: Narrator

text: For it is impossible that the blood of bulls and goats should take away sins.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Therefore when he comes into the world, he says,
“You didn’t desire sacrifice and offering,
    but you prepared a body for me.
speaker: Narrator

text: You had no pleasure in whole burnt offerings and sacrifices for sin.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then I said, ‘Behold, I have come (in the scroll of the book it is written of me)
    to do your will, O God.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: Previously saying, “Sacrifices and offerings and whole burnt offerings and sacrifices for sin you didn’t desire, neither had pleasure in them” (those which are offered according to the law),
speaker: Narrator

text: then he has said, “Behold, I have come to do your will.” He takes away the first, that he may establish the second,
speaker: Narrator

text: by which will we have been sanctified through the offering of the body of Jesus Christ once for all.
speaker: Narrator

text: Every priest indeed stands day by day serving and offering often the same sacrifices, which can never take away sins,
speaker: Narrator

text: but he, when he had offered one sacrifice for sins forever, sat down on the right hand of God,
speaker: Narrator

text: from that time waiting until his enemies are made the footstool of his feet.
speaker: Narrator

text: For by one offering he has perfected forever those who are being sanctified.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Holy Spirit also testifies to us, for after saying,
speaker: Narrator

text:
“This is the covenant that I will make with them
    after those days,” says the Lord,
“I will put my laws on their heart,
    I will also write them on their mind;”
then he says,
speaker: Narrator

text: “I will remember their sins and their iniquities no more.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Now where remission of these is, there is no more offering for sin.
speaker: Narrator

text: Having therefore, brothers, boldness to enter into the holy place by the blood of Jesus,
speaker: Narrator

text: by the way which he dedicated for us, a new and living way, through the veil, that is to say, his flesh,
speaker: Narrator

text: and having a great priest over God’s house,
speaker: Narrator

text: let’s draw near with a true heart in fullness of faith, having our hearts sprinkled from an evil conscience and having our body washed with pure water,
speaker: Narrator

text: let’s hold fast the confession of our hope without wavering; for he who promised is faithful.
speaker: Narrator

text: Let’s consider how to provoke one another to love and good works,
speaker: Narrator

text: not forsaking our own assembling together, as the custom of some is, but exhorting one another, and so much the more as you see the Day approaching.
speaker: Narrator

text: For if we sin willfully after we have received the knowledge of the truth, there remains no more a sacrifice for sins,
speaker: Narrator

text: but a certain fearful expectation of judgment, and a fierceness of fire which will devour the adversaries.
speaker: Narrator

text: A man who disregards Moses’ law dies without compassion on the word of two or three witnesses.
speaker: Narrator

text: How much worse punishment do you think he will be judged worthy of who has trodden under foot the Son of God, and has counted the blood of the covenant with which he was sanctified an unholy thing, and has insulted the Spirit of grace?
speaker: Narrator

text: For we know him who said, “Vengeance belongs to me. I will repay,” says the Lord. Again, “The Lord will judge his people.”
speaker: Narrator

text: It is a fearful thing to fall into the hands of the living God.
speaker: Narrator

text: But remember the former days, in which, after you were enlightened, you endured a great struggle with sufferings:
speaker: Narrator

text: partly, being exposed to both reproaches and oppressions, and partly, becoming partakers with those who were treated so.
speaker: Narrator

text: For you both had compassion on me in my chains and joyfully accepted the plundering of your possessions, knowing that you have for yourselves a better possession and an enduring one in the heavens.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore don’t throw away your boldness, which has a great reward.
speaker: Narrator

text: For you need endurance so that, having done the will of God, you may receive the promise.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“In a very little while,
    he who comes will come and will not wait.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But the righteous one will live by faith.
    If he shrinks back, my soul has no pleasure in him.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But we are not of those who shrink back to destruction, but of those who have faith to the saving of the soul.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now faith is assurance of things hoped for, proof of things not seen.
speaker: Narrator

text: For by this, the elders obtained approval.
speaker: Narrator

text: By faith we understand that the universe has been framed by the word of God, so that what is seen has not been made out of things which are visible.
speaker: Narrator

text: By faith Abel offered to God a more excellent sacrifice than Cain, through which he had testimony given to him that he was righteous, God testifying with respect to his gifts; and through it he, being dead, still speaks.
speaker: Narrator

text: By faith Enoch was taken away, so that he wouldn’t see death, and he was not found, because God translated him. For he has had testimony given to him that before his translation he had been well pleasing to God.
speaker: Narrator

text: Without faith it is impossible to be well pleasing to him, for he who comes to God must believe that he exists, and that he is a rewarder of those who seek him.
speaker: Narrator

text: By faith Noah, being warned about things not yet seen, moved with godly fear, prepared a ship for the saving of his house, through which he condemned the world and became heir of the righteousness which is according to faith.
speaker: Narrator

text: By faith Abraham, when he was called, obeyed to go out to the place which he was to receive for an inheritance. He went out, not knowing where he went.
speaker: Narrator

text: By faith he lived as an alien in the land of promise, as in a land not his own, dwelling in tents with Isaac and Jacob, the heirs with him of the same promise.
speaker: Narrator

text: For he was looking for the city which has foundations, whose builder and maker is God.
speaker: Narrator

text: By faith even Sarah herself received power to conceive, and she bore a child when she was past age, since she counted him faithful who had promised.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore as many as the stars of the sky in multitude, and as innumerable as the sand which is by the sea shore, were fathered by one man, and him as good as dead.
speaker: Narrator

text: These all died in faith, not having received the promises, but having seen them and embraced them from afar, and having confessed that they were strangers and pilgrims on the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text: For those who say such things make it clear that they are seeking a country of their own.
speaker: Narrator

text: If indeed they had been thinking of that country from which they went out, they would have had enough time to return.
speaker: Narrator

text: But now they desire a better country, that is, a heavenly one. Therefore God is not ashamed of them, to be called their God, for he has prepared a city for them.
speaker: Narrator

text: By faith, Abraham, being tested, offered up Isaac. Yes, he who had gladly received the promises was offering up his only born son,
speaker: Narrator

text: to whom it was said, “Your offspring will be accounted as from Isaac,”
speaker: Narrator

text: concluding that God is able to raise up even from the dead. Figuratively speaking, he also did receive him back from the dead.
speaker: Narrator

text: By faith Isaac blessed Jacob and Esau, even concerning things to come.
speaker: Narrator

text: By faith Jacob, when he was dying, blessed each of the sons of Joseph, and worshiped, leaning on the top of his staff.
speaker: Narrator

text: By faith Joseph, when his end was near, made mention of the departure of the children of Israel, and gave instructions concerning his bones.
speaker: Narrator

text: By faith Moses, when he was born, was hidden for three months by his parents, because they saw that he was a beautiful child; and they were not afraid of the king’s commandment.
speaker: Narrator

text: By faith Moses, when he had grown up, refused to be called the son of Pharaoh’s daughter,
speaker: Narrator

text: choosing rather to share ill treatment with God’s people than to enjoy the pleasures of sin for a time,
speaker: Narrator

text: considering the reproach of Christ greater riches than the treasures of Egypt; for he looked to the reward.
speaker: Narrator

text: By faith he left Egypt, not fearing the wrath of the king; for he endured, as seeing him who is invisible.
speaker: Narrator

text: By faith he kept the Passover and the sprinkling of the blood, that the destroyer of the firstborn should not touch them.
speaker: Narrator

text: By faith they passed through the Red Sea as on dry land. When the Egyptians tried to do so, they were swallowed up.
speaker: Narrator

text: By faith the walls of Jericho fell down after they had been encircled for seven days.
speaker: Narrator

text: By faith Rahab the prostitute didn’t perish with those who were disobedient, having received the spies in peace.
speaker: Narrator

text: What more shall I say? For the time would fail me if I told of Gideon, Barak, Samson, Jephthah, David, Samuel, and the prophets—
speaker: Narrator

text: who through faith subdued kingdoms, worked out righteousness, obtained promises, stopped the mouths of lions,
speaker: Narrator

text: quenched the power of fire, escaped the edge of the sword, from weakness were made strong, grew mighty in war, and caused foreign armies to flee.
speaker: Narrator

text: Women received their dead by resurrection. Others were tortured, not accepting their deliverance, that they might obtain a better resurrection.
speaker: Narrator

text: Others were tried by mocking and scourging, yes, moreover by bonds and imprisonment.
speaker: Narrator

text: They were stoned. They were sawn apart. They were tempted. They were slain with the sword. They went around in sheep skins and in goat skins; being destitute, afflicted, ill-treated—
speaker: Narrator

text: of whom the world was not worthy—wandering in deserts, mountains, caves, and the holes of the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text: These all, having been commended for their faith, didn’t receive the promise,
speaker: Narrator

text: God having provided some better thing concerning us, so that apart from us they should not be made perfect.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore let’s also, seeing we are surrounded by so great a cloud of witnesses, lay aside every weight and the sin which so easily entangles us, and let’s run with perseverance the race that is set before us,
speaker: Narrator

text: looking to Jesus, the author and perfecter of faith, who for the joy that was set before him endured the cross, despising its shame, and has sat down at the right hand of the throne of God.
speaker: Narrator

text: For consider him who has endured such contradiction of sinners against himself, that you don’t grow weary, fainting in your souls.
speaker: Narrator

text: You have not yet resisted to blood, striving against sin.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
for whom the Lord loves, he disciplines,
    and chastises every son whom he receives.”
speaker: Narrator

text: It is for discipline that you endure. God deals with you as with children, for what son is there whom his father doesn’t discipline?
speaker: Narrator

text: But if you are without discipline, of which all have been made partakers, then you are illegitimate, and not children.
speaker: Narrator

text: Furthermore, we had the fathers of our flesh to chasten us, and we paid them respect. Shall we not much rather be in subjection to the Father of spirits and live?
speaker: Narrator

text: For they indeed for a few days disciplined us as seemed good to them, but he for our profit, that we may be partakers of his holiness.
speaker: Narrator

text: All chastening seems for the present to be not joyous but grievous; yet afterward it yields the peaceful fruit of righteousness to those who have been trained by it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore lift up the hands that hang down and the feeble knees,
speaker: Narrator

text: and make straight paths for your feet, so what is lame may not be dislocated, but rather be healed.
speaker: Narrator

text: Follow after peace with all men, and the sanctification without which no man will see the Lord,
speaker: Narrator

text: looking carefully lest there be any man who falls short of the grace of God, lest any root of bitterness springing up trouble you and many be defiled by it,
speaker: Narrator

text: lest there be any sexually immoral person or profane person, like Esau, who sold his birthright for one meal.
speaker: Narrator

text: For you know that even when he afterward desired to inherit the blessing, he was rejected, for he found no place for a change of mind though he sought it diligently with tears.
speaker: Narrator

text: For you have not come to a mountain that might be touched and that burned with fire, and to blackness, darkness, storm,
speaker: Narrator

text: the sound of a trumpet, and the voice of words; which those who heard it begged that not one more word should be spoken to them,
speaker: Narrator

text: for they could not stand that which was commanded, “If even an animal touches the mountain, it shall be stoned”.
speaker: Narrator

text: So fearful was the appearance that Moses said, “I am terrified and trembling.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But you have come to Mount Zion and to the city of the living God, the heavenly Jerusalem, and to innumerable multitudes of angels,
speaker: Narrator

text: to the festal gathering and assembly of the firstborn who are enrolled in heaven, to God the Judge of all, to the spirits of just men made perfect,
speaker: Narrator

text: to Jesus, the mediator of a new covenant, and to the blood of sprinkling that speaks better than that of Abel.
speaker: Narrator

text: See that you don’t refuse him who speaks. For if they didn’t escape when they refused him who warned on the earth, how much more will we not escape who turn away from him who warns from heaven,
speaker: Narrator

text: whose voice shook the earth then, but now he has promised, saying, “Yet once more I will shake not only the earth, but also the heavens.”
speaker: Narrator

text: This phrase, “Yet once more” signifies the removing of those things that are shaken, as of things that have been made, that those things which are not shaken may remain.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore, receiving a Kingdom that can’t be shaken, let’s have grace, through which we serve God acceptably, with reverence and awe,
speaker: Narrator

text: for our God is a consuming fire.
speaker: Narrator

text: Let brotherly love continue.
speaker: Narrator

text: Don’t forget to show hospitality to strangers, for in doing so, some have entertained angels without knowing it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Remember those who are in bonds, as bound with them, and those who are ill-treated, since you are also in the body.
speaker: Narrator

text: Let marriage be held in honor among all, and let the bed be undefiled; but God will judge the sexually immoral and adulterers.
speaker: Narrator

text: Be free from the love of money, content with such things as you have, for he has said, “I will in no way leave you, neither will I in any way forsake you.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
So that with good courage we say,
“The Lord is my helper. I will not fear.
    What can man do to me?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Remember your leaders, men who spoke to you the word of God, and considering the results of their conduct, imitate their faith.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jesus Christ is the same yesterday, today, and forever.
speaker: Narrator

text: Don’t be carried away by various and strange teachings, for it is good that the heart be established by grace, not by foods, through which those who were so occupied were not benefited.
speaker: Narrator

text: We have an altar from which those who serve the holy tabernacle have no right to eat.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the bodies of those animals, whose blood is brought into the holy place by the high priest as an offering for sin, are burned outside of the camp.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore Jesus also, that he might sanctify the people through his own blood, suffered outside of the gate.
speaker: Narrator

text: Let’s therefore go out to him outside of the camp, bearing his reproach.
speaker: Narrator

text: For we don’t have here an enduring city, but we seek that which is to come.
speaker: Narrator

text: Through him, then, let’s offer up a sacrifice of praise to God continually, that is, the fruit of lips which proclaim allegiance to his name.
speaker: Narrator

text: But don’t forget to be doing good and sharing, for with such sacrifices God is well pleased.
speaker: Narrator

text: Obey your leaders and submit to them, for they watch on behalf of your souls, as those who will give account, that they may do this with joy and not with groaning, for that would be unprofitable for you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Pray for us, for we are persuaded that we have a good conscience, desiring to live honorably in all things.
speaker: Narrator

text: I strongly urge you to do this, that I may be restored to you sooner.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now may the God of peace, who brought again from the dead the great shepherd of the sheep with the blood of an eternal covenant, our Lord Jesus,
speaker: Narrator

text: make you complete in every good work to do his will, working in you that which is well pleasing in his sight, through Jesus Christ, to whom be the glory forever and ever. Amen.
speaker: Narrator

text: But I exhort you, brothers, endure the word of exhortation, for I have written to you in few words.
speaker: Narrator

text: Know that our brother Timothy has been freed, with whom, if he comes shortly, I will see you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Greet all of your leaders and all the saints. The Italians greet you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Grace be with you all. Amen.
speaker: Narrator
